Title: Mechanistic and topological explanations in medicine: the case of medical genetics and network medicine
Sentence: Thagard takes the example of the SARS coronavirus.

Title: Mechanistic and topological explanations in medicine: the case of medical genetics and network medicine
Sentence: It is possible to describe the mechanism of SARS infection by identifying the parts and the activities of the virus and of the host.

Title: Mechanistic and topological explanations in medicine: the case of medical genetics and network medicine
Sentence: It is the way these different parts and activities are organized in a continuous spatial-temporal process that allows the SARS coronavirus to infect the host cell, then to generate and cause SARS symptoms.

Title: Mechanistic and topological explanations in medicine: the case of medical genetics and network medicine
Sentence: I will especially focus on one of the main tools of network medicine: the diseasome whose aim is to represent as a network the relationships between every human disease gene and every human disease.

Title: Mechanistic and topological explanations in medicine: the case of medical genetics and network medicine
Sentence: Some diseases are caused by the immune system becoming overactive and attacking parts of the body, as when white blood cells remove myelin from axons between neurons, producing the symptoms of multiple sclerosis.

Title: Mechanistic and topological explanations in medicine: the case of medical genetics and network medicine
Sentence: The final major category of human disease is cancer, and the genetic mutations that convert a normal cell into an invasive carcinoma, as well as the biochemical pathways that are thereby affected, are becoming well mapped out.

Title: Mechanistic and topological explanations in medicine: the case of medical genetics and network medicine
Sentence: Network medicine is a recent research program, mainly developed by the team of Albert-László Barabási Barabási and Oltvai 2004; Barabási 2007) and born from the synthesis between the concept of "human disease genes", the development of systems biology and medicine and the formalization of network theory-three theoretical pillars that I am now going to detail.

Title: Mechanistic and topological explanations in medicine: the case of medical genetics and network medicine
Sentence: The concept of "human disease genes" rests on a double distinction .

Title: Mechanistic and topological explanations in medicine: the case of medical genetics and network medicine
Sentence: First of all, it aims at distinguishing between human genes and non-human genes .

Title: Mechanistic and topological explanations in medicine: the case of medical genetics and network medicine
Sentence: The point is that human disease genes may have specific characteristics that differ from non-disease genes.

Title: Mechanistic and topological explanations in medicine: the case of medical genetics and network medicine
Sentence: In order to do so, network medicine relies on the systematic comparison between the human interactome and various disease networks .

Title: Mechanistic and topological explanations in medicine: the case of medical genetics and network medicine
Sentence: A complete human interactome that would roughly incorportate 25,000 human genes, around 10 6 proteins, and their interactions, is yet to be drawn.

Title: Mechanistic and topological explanations in medicine: the case of medical genetics and network medicine
Sentence: The partial human interactome that are used nowadays, roughly incorporates 50,000 unique proteins, involved in around 200,000 interactions .

Title: Mechanistic and topological explanations in medicine: the case of medical genetics and network medicine
Sentence: In order to do so, network medicine relies on three theoretical pillars, namely systems biology and medicine, the concept of human disease genes and network theory the diseasome and on its relationships to the interactome.

Title: Mechanistic and topological explanations in medicine: the case of medical genetics and network medicine
Sentence: The diseasome intends to represent the relationships between human diseases and diseasecausing genes.

Title: Mechanistic and topological explanations in medicine: the case of medical genetics and network medicine
Sentence: One set corresponds to all known genetic disorders, whereas the other set corresponds to all known disease genes in the human genome.

Title: Mechanistic and topological explanations in medicine: the case of medical genetics and network medicine
Sentence: On the one hand, there is the human disease network , where diseases are nodes and two diseases are connected if they share a same gene in their physiopathology .

Title: Mechanistic and topological explanations in medicine: the case of medical genetics and network medicine
Sentence: On the other hand, there is the human disease gene network where genes are nodes and two genes are connected if they are involved in the physiopathology of the same disease .

Title: Mechanistic and topological explanations in medicine: the case of medical genetics and network medicine
Sentence: The second one is to characterize the specific properties of the "human diseases genes" by adding biological information on these genes to the topological analysis of the network.

Title: Mechanistic and topological explanations in medicine: the case of medical genetics and network medicine
Sentence: Finally, the third aim of the disease is to be compared to the interactome, in order to find some general organizing principles of the genetics of human disease.

Title: Mechanistic and topological explanations in medicine: the case of medical genetics and network medicine
Sentence: Although OMIM is the most up-to-date repository on the genetics of human disease, it is important to specify that it was originally restricted to monogenic disorders and has only in recent years expanded to include complex traits and the associated genetic mutations.

Title: Mechanistic and topological explanations in medicine: the case of medical genetics and network medicine
Sentence: The second one is a local analysis that compares topological properties from the human disease genes network with biological information on the pathophysiological role of these human disease genes.

Title: Mechanistic and topological explanations in medicine: the case of medical genetics and network medicine
Sentence: The third one consists in comparing topological properties of the human disease genes network with topological properties of the interactome, which represents the set of possible biological interactions in a human organism.

Title: Mechanistic and topological explanations in medicine: the case of medical genetics and network medicine
Sentence: In the human disease network, as in the human disease gene network, it appears that the nodes are highly interconnected and that the degree distribution in both networks follows a power law distribution .

Title: Mechanistic and topological explanations in medicine: the case of medical genetics and network medicine
Sentence: To put it differently, from a topological point of view, this means that the human disease network and the disease gene network are scale-free networks.

Title: Mechanistic and topological explanations in medicine: the case of medical genetics and network medicine
Sentence: Indeed, would each human disease have a distinct genetic origin, the human disease network would either only exhibit disconnected sub-networks, composed of few isolated nodes, each one corresponding to a disease, or would be composed of small subgroups of similar disorders.

Title: Mechanistic and topological explanations in medicine: the case of medical genetics and network medicine
Sentence: The second analysis is a local analysis: the aim is to test this hypothesis of a functional clustering of human disease genes and to analyze the behavior and the properties of genes that are involved in the same disease.

Title: Mechanistic and topological explanations in medicine: the case of medical genetics and network medicine
Sentence: The third analysis gets to another level, since it aims at comparing the diseasome with the interactome 7 and at characterizing human disease genes properties compared to human non-disease genes properties.

Title: Mechanistic and topological explanations in medicine: the case of medical genetics and network medicine
Sentence: Since such experiments cannot be conducted on humans, a human gene is considered essential if the knockout of its murine orthologue leads to the death of the mutant .

Title: Mechanistic and topological explanations in medicine: the case of medical genetics and network medicine
Sentence: Since previous analyses of the yeast protein interaction network seemed to prove that essential genes constitute central hubs in the yeast , human disease genes were expected to be essential genes and to constitute hubs in the diseasome.

Title: Mechanistic and topological explanations in medicine: the case of medical genetics and network medicine
Sentence: Indeed, a first topological analysis of the interactome seems to prove that proteins produced by human diseases genes have a higher connectivity than proteins whose genes are not involved in human diseases.

Title: Mechanistic and topological explanations in medicine: the case of medical genetics and network medicine
Sentence: So, if centrality is taken as a proxy for being essential, this first analysis seems to confirm that human diseases genes are essential genes.

Title: Mechanistic and topological explanations in medicine: the case of medical genetics and network medicine
Sentence: However, when using murin orthologues of the human disease genes to determine a given gene is essentiality, the situation appears to be more complex: over the 7,533 genes of the reconstructed interactome, the researchers identified 1267 essential genes that are not associated to any known disease.

Title: Mechanistic and topological explanations in medicine: the case of medical genetics and network medicine
Sentence: Over the 1,777 human disease genes represented in the diseasome, there are 398 essential human disease genes and 1,379 human disease genes that are not essential.

Title: Mechanistic and topological explanations in medicine: the case of medical genetics and network medicine
Sentence: To put it shortly, it seems that the vast majority of human disease genes are not essential genes, do not encode hubs and are located at the periphery of the interactome, while a few of them are essential genes, encode hubs and are located at the center of the interactome.

Title: Mechanistic and topological explanations in medicine: the case of medical genetics and network medicine
Sentence: To explain this surprising result, the researchers made an evolutionary hypothesis: the vast majority of human disease genes are non-essential and centered at the periphery of the interactome because, when mutated, they only lead to disease instead of leading to death in utero.

Title: Mechanistic and topological explanations in medicine: the case of medical genetics and network medicine
Sentence: For example, the local hypothesis, according to which genes and gene products that are involved in the same disease have an increased tendency to interact together and to belong to the same disease module, depends highly both on a topological property of the diseasome and on mechanistic information on the human disease genes represented in the diseasome .

Title: Mechanistic and topological explanations in medicine: the case of medical genetics and network medicine
Sentence: In a similar way, interpreting the degree of essentiality-centrality of human diseases genes is also highly dependent on the import of external mechanistic information on the systematic knockout of their murin orthologues.

Title: Mechanistic and topological explanations in medicine: the case of medical genetics and network medicine
Sentence: First, we may wonder why the diseasome has such topological properties, how it has evolved to be a scale-free network, why some functional disease modules are more robust than others to external perturbations and why the human disease genes are mostly at the periphery of the interactome.

Title: Mechanistic and topological explanations in medicine: the case of medical genetics and network medicine
Sentence: I have mentioned some evolutionary hypotheses about this last point: human disease genes would be located at the periphery of the interactome, because their mutations do not lead to death in utero.

Title: Mechanistic and topological explanations in medicine: the case of medical genetics and network medicine
Sentence: By relying on the topological properties of the human disease gene network, network medicine provides an explanation of the common genetic origin of diseases, reinterprets the concept of genetic diseases through the identification of disease modules and explains the difference between monogenic and polygenic diseases as a matter of functional redundancy and robustness.

Title: Translational Genomics in Neurocritical Care: a Review
Sentence: Translational genomics represents a diverse collection of research approaches that leverage human genomics and model systems to identify new approaches to treat and prevent disease and improve healthcare .

Title: Translational Genomics in Neurocritical Care: a Review
Sentence: Forward translation depends on the relevance of the model system to human disease, both in terms of the physiologic responses to disease or insult, as well as the approach taken to perturb the system.

Title: Translational Genomics in Neurocritical Care: a Review
Sentence: For instance, the human applicability of genomic studies of the response to traumatic brain injury in a mouse model require that the mouse is response to TBI is analogous to a human is, and that the approach taken to Pavlos Myserlis and Farid Radmanesh contributed equally to this work.

Title: Translational Genomics in Neurocritical Care: a Review
Sentence: create a TBI in the mouse provokes a similar pattern of injury seen in human TBI .

Title: Translational Genomics in Neurocritical Care: a Review
Sentence: As such, a great deal of careful work is required to demonstrate the validity of these model systems before the results arising from them can be judged relevant to human disease.

Title: Translational Genomics in Neurocritical Care: a Review
Sentence: The challenges of bridging this divide are illustrated by the universal failure of neuroprotection mechanisms that reached human trials in the last several decades, essentially all of which had promising model system data in preclinical development .

Title: Translational Genomics in Neurocritical Care: a Review
Sentence: Furthermore, because genomic data is both identifiable and can potentially lead to discrimination, human genomic studies require complex consent and data management procedures .

Title: Translational Genomics in Neurocritical Care: a Review
Sentence: In neurocritical care, the relative rarity of many of the diseases we encounter, coupled with the challenges of critical illness and surrogate consent make human genomic studies all the more difficult to execute effectively .

Title: Translational Genomics in Neurocritical Care: a Review
Sentence: In advance of the Human Genome Project and the HapMap Consortium, genetic studies were confined to the study of candidate genes and lower-resolution genome-wide techniques such as categorization of restriction fragment length polymorphisms , tandem repeats, and microsatellites .

Title: Translational Genomics in Neurocritical Care: a Review
Sentence: With these breakthroughs and a number of landmark evolutions that followed, case/control and population-based GWAS have led to the identification of over 11,000 associations with human diseases and other traits .

Title: Translational Genomics in Neurocritical Care: a Review
Sentence: Obviously there is an enormous disconnect between the discovery of genetic loci and leveraging of this information for human benefit, which is where the translational genomic work that serves as the topic of the present review becomes relevant .

Title: Translational Genomics in Neurocritical Care: a Review
Sentence: Because the coding exome is only~2% of the overall genome, it is more cost-effective than WGS, but debate continues as to which is the more appropriate tool for large-scale study of the human genome .

Title: Translational Genomics in Neurocritical Care: a Review
Sentence: Obviously genomic research need not be limited solely to human studies.

Title: Translational Genomics in Neurocritical Care: a Review
Sentence: A wealth of information about disease pathogenesis and response to injury can be gleaned from model systems of human conditions using genomic and transcriptomic approaches.

Title: Translational Genomics in Neurocritical Care: a Review
Sentence: At a minimum, these elegant studies can help to identify relevant cell types important in the response to injury, highlighting testable hypotheses that may be important in human conditions, all with access to tissues and control over experimental conditions that would never be possible in human-based research.

Title: Translational Genomics in Neurocritical Care: a Review
Sentence: Forward genomic translation begins with model systems with the goal of using the measured associations in these models to derive insight into biological mechanisms that may also be relevant in human disease.

Title: Translational Genomics in Neurocritical Care: a Review
Sentence: Forward translation requires wellcharacterized models that are often designed to mimic the human exposures of interest as closely as possible.
